entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from bargaigner

def.dt: :an agreement between parties settling what each gives or receives in a transaction between them or what course of action or policy each pursues in respect to the other
:something acquired by or as if by bargaining
:an advantageous purchase at that price the car is a bargain
:a transaction, situation, or event regarded in the light of its results a bad bargain
:besides tastes good and is good for you, into the bargain

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French bargaigner, probably of Germanic origin; akin to Old English borgian to borrow bury

def.dt: :to negotiate over the terms of a purchase, agreement, or contract :haggle
:to bring to a desired level by bargaining bargain a price down
:to sell or dispose of by bargaining
:expect more work than I bargained for
:a section of a store (as the basement) where merchandise is sold at reduced prices
:the negotiation of an agreement between a prosecutor and a defendant whereby the defendant is permitted to plead guilty to a reduced charge
